awd_titl_txt: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Australia
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds Christina Forbes of the University of Delaware to conduct a research project in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences area during the summer of 2013 at the University of Queensland in St. Lucia, Queensland, Australia.  The project title is "Synthetic Modifications to the Cyclic Protein Kalata B1." The host scientist is Dr. David Craik.

Cyclic peptides (cyclotides) are small proteins with a continuous circular backbone, forming a structure that is resistant to thermal and enzymatic degradation. Kalata B1 is a plant-derived cyclotide woven with three disulfide bonds, creating an exceptionally stable structure with anti-HIV activity. Due to its short sequence, there are few sites for functionalization in Kalata B1 that do not change its core structural stability. This project broadens the potential applications of Kalata B1 by incorporating non-natural amino acids with bioorthogonal chemical "handles," generating a uniquely versatile and stable platform for molecular scaffolding. These integrated "handles" can be further modified to decorate synthetic Kalata B1 with small molecules, materials, and proteins for applications in materials science and small molecule library screening.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language.   These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.  Furthermore, this fellowship will establish an international, interdisciplinary collaboration based on the design, synthesis, and applications of modifiable cyclotides for biomolecular scaffolding. On completion of this work, the results will be published in a peer-reviewed journal so that other researchers may use cyclotide scaffolds in new applications.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Background

     Proteins are the biological machines that control cellular function and signaling. They are constructed from long chains of amino acids, which fold onto themselves to generate a three-dimensional structure. Both the reactive nature of the amino acids and the globular structure ultimately dictate the functions of proteins. By modifying the amino acid sequence or re-engineering the structure of proteins, new functions and properties can be introduced into these biological molecules. Applications of protein engineering can range from polymers and materials science to pharmaceuticals and biomedical engineering.

     Cyclotides, a class of small circular proteins, are produced naturally in plants, and are exceptionally stable to heat and digestive enzymes. Considering their relatively small size and remarkable stability, cyclotides would be an ideal template for protein engineering. Many cyclotides have been produced synthetically, and some cyclotides have been modified to introduce new functions using a technique called grafting. Grafting integrates a cyclotide with an amino acid sequence that has properties of interest, which effectively fuses the stability properties of the cyclotide with the functional properties of the sequence of interest. However, due to the nature of grafting, only amino acid sequences of a limited size can be incorporated into cyclotides. Many other useful molecules, such as drug molecules, fluorescent labels, or polymers can not be incorporated into cyclotides using this method. This project aims to introduce a new method for engineering cyclotides, where chemical “handles” are built into the cyclic backbone, using synthetic amino acids. By only introducing single, modified amino acids, the native structure and stability of the cyclotide is maintained. These modified amino acids would serve as sites for attaching a variety of different molecules using simple, general reactions. In this manner, rapid access to a diverse library of cyclotides with different functions would be synthetically more accessible, less time-consuming, and less expensive than developing a similar library using the grafting technique.

Scientific Outcomes

     In this project, I successfully synthesized a derivatized version of Kalata B1, a well characterized cyclotide, containing one synthetic amino acid with a chemical “handle.” I briefly examined the structure of this modified cyclotide, and established that the structure was consistent with the native Kalata B1. This experiment validated that this integrated chemical “handle” is well tolerated within the cyclotide structure, and does not affect the global conformational fold. I also developed a new method for installing the chemical “handles” into cyclotides following synthesis of the linear precursors, which avoids the need to independently synthesize the modified amino acids. This new method is more general and practical, and would allow researchers to apply this technique to other cyclotides, or incorporate different chemical “handles.” Researchers at the host laboratory and I have begun initial studies and reaction optimization to attach some small amino acid sequences to the modified Kalata B1. Currently, we are working on synthesizing a new version of Kalata B1 that contains three different chemical “handles,” so that this derivatized cyclotide can function as a platform for multiple, simultaneous modifications.

Additional Outcomes

     This project initiated an international collaboration between the United States and Australia, combining the efforts between cyclotide experts and bioorganic chemists. It provided an opportunity to work in the Australian lab...

Background

     Proteins are the biological machines that control cellular function and signaling. They are constructed from long chains of amino acids, which fold onto themselves to generate a three-dimensional structure. Both the reactive nature of the amino acids and the globular structure ultimately dictate the functions of proteins. By modifying the amino acid sequence or re-engineering the structure of proteins, new functions and properties can be introduced into these biological molecules. Applications of protein engineering can range from polymers and materials science to pharmaceuticals and biomedical engineering.

     Cyclotides, a class of small circular proteins, are produced naturally in plants, and are exceptionally stable to heat and digestive enzymes. Considering their relatively small size and remarkable stability, cyclotides would be an ideal template for protein engineering. Many cyclotides have been produced synthetically, and some cyclotides have been modified to introduce new functions using a technique called grafting. Grafting integrates a cyclotide with an amino acid sequence that has properties of interest, which effectively fuses the stability properties of the cyclotide with the functional properties of the sequence of interest. However, due to the nature of grafting, only amino acid sequences of a limited size can be incorporated into cyclotides. Many other useful molecules, such as drug molecules, fluorescent labels, or polymers can not be incorporated into cyclotides using this method. This project aims to introduce a new method for engineering cyclotides, where chemical "handles" are built into the cyclic backbone, using synthetic amino acids. By only introducing single, modified amino acids, the native structure and stability of the cyclotide is maintained. These modified amino acids would serve as sites for attaching a variety of different molecules using simple, general reactions. In this manner, rapid access to a diverse library of cyclotides with different functions would be synthetically more accessible, less time-consuming, and less expensive than developing a similar library using the grafting technique.

Scientific Outcomes

     In this project, I successfully synthesized a derivatized version of Kalata B1, a well characterized cyclotide, containing one synthetic amino acid with a chemical "handle." I briefly examined the structure of this modified cyclotide, and established that the structure was consistent with the native Kalata B1. This experiment validated that this integrated chemical "handle" is well tolerated within the cyclotide structure, and does not affect the global conformational fold. I also developed a new method for installing the chemical "handles" into cyclotides following synthesis of the linear precursors, which avoids the need to independently synthesize the modified amino acids. This new method is more general and practical, and would allow researchers to apply this technique to other cyclotides, or incorporate different chemical "handles." Researchers at the host laboratory and I have begun initial studies and reaction optimization to attach some small amino acid sequences to the modified Kalata B1. Currently, we are working on synthesizing a new version of Kalata B1 that contains three different chemical "handles," so that this derivatized cyclotide can function as a platform for multiple, simultaneous modifications.

Additional Outcomes

     This project initiated an international collaboration between the United States and Australia, combining the efforts between cyclotide experts and bioorganic chemists. It provided an opportunity to work in the Australian lab for eight weeks. During this time, I learned, first-hand, new techniques in cyclotide chemistry, and taught the collaborative researchers about methods in modifying amino acids and proteins.
